creditline: Gift of the Clark Center for Japanese Art & Culture; formerly given to the Center by H. Ed Robison, in memory of his beloved wife Ulrike Pietzner Robison
inscription: right: [?文鳥] {jizuri, Shōwa ninen saku, Bunchō} | bottom, in pencil: Buncho | Toshi Yoshida
medium: Woodblock print, ink and color on paper
text: As a child, Tōshi suffered from polio meningitis, which left one of his legs permanently paralyzed and made normal childhood activities impossible. Instead, he distracted himself by sketching and painting. To distinguish his work from the landscape art of his prominent father, he concentrated at the beginning of his career on the illustration of animals.
title: Java Sparrow
